posts.cooked: Hello, we would like to know if we can install the pidgeon very close to two motors and if the electromagnetic field of the motors would affect the orientation of the pidgeon?

posts.name: Justin Nesselrotte
posts.cooked:
Great question! You should check out the Hardware Manual Here and look for the section titled “Avoid Magnetic/Ferromagnetic materials”.

It’s a slightly more complex answer than a simple yes or no.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked:
While it’s not settled scientifically, some research suggests that homing pigeons can (to an extent) detect electromagnetic fields and use them to navigate.

EDIT: nvm, wrong kind of pigeon

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Also, from the manual: “We recommend leaving the compass disabled for indoor robotics applications as this means customers can use the Pigeon 2 as is, with no supplemental calibration procedures.”  (I believe this is the default config setting.)

If you are not using the compass, you should be fine – but that’s an opinion.  I have seem these placed quite close to motors, with no apparent issue.  The accelerometer portion of the IMU should be fairly tolerant of the kinds of fields you see outside a motor.  But, any distance you can get is probably worth getting.  Consider having mounting holes/whatever so you can move the IMU if you need to, or so you can check for effects in your specific case.
For the record, I’ve had (very powerful) motors butting right up against Pigeons and not a single issue came out of it. No compass/magnetometer disabling or anything else to speak of.

posts.name: garyk
posts.cooked: My first thought was the same.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: The strength of a magnetic field decreases proportional to the distance cubed. Relatively small separations will dramatically reduce the field strength. One would have to conduct some tests to ensure that there are no significant effects.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: I wouldn’t run “high” voltage wires across it…just in case.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: The highest voltage allowed in an FRC control system is 24V. The strength of an electric field is proportional to the inverse of the distance. At such a low voltage and the proximities that are achievable, the electric field effects would be insignificant.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
We saw interference…we moved the wires away…no issue.  At least not with the Pigeon…

It was better to move them (we had 5 sets of power wires and the battery cable crossing it).  Onesy twosy…you may be correct.  These wires aren’t exactly shielded or aviation rated.   We moved them after week 1…week 2 we didn’t see the issues we had.

Don’t get me wrong…we still had issues…that was due to coding.  And towards the middle or end of week 2…the drive was working way better.

Auto…was a different story…that was due to improper PID values.  That has since been fixed…just in case we were able to go to State.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
One has to dig down to the root cause of a problem to find correlation between cause and effect. Otherwise, an inappropriate solution will be applied and the problem will reappear later.

Sometimes, there will be multiple problems and one has to sort through which symptom correlates with which cause. It’s not easy to do.

From my professional experience doing decades of R&D work on high-power electrical equipment, the currents and voltages in an FRC robot are highly unlikely to cause interference with the kinds of separations that are easy to achieve.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
The short answer is yes. Running high current motor wire next to, or wrapped around (I’ve seen some interesting choices) a Pigeon, or NaxEx can and will scramble the magnetic field these devices use.

Your best chance of success is to avoid doing that to the greatest extent possible.
